description: We‚Äôll take you through how the PASF has changed over the years and how you can take advantage of everything it has to offer.
content: Analyzing Google's Desktop "People Also Search For" Box Search Engines | Marketing Industry | SEO Analytics By: Roger MozBot May 27, 2019 Table of Contents Copied! By: Roger MozBot May 27, 2019 Analyzing Google's Desktop "People Also Search For" Box Search Engines | Marketing Industry | SEO Analytics This blog post was originally published on the STAT blog. The ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù result isn‚Äôt new to desktop SERPs, but the rejigging it received in February last year turned it into an entirely different box worth investigating. And since we know you‚Äôre wondering what‚Äôs inside, we played the Somerset to your Mills and took a look for you. What we found was an amped up, URL-centric version of the original PASF box, the ‚ÄúPeople also ask‚Äù box, and the ‚ÄúSearches related to‚Äù you see at the bottom of the SERP ‚Äî it‚Äôs a keyword goldmine and chock-full of content ideas, straight from the horse‚Äôs mouth (Google). We‚Äôll take you through how the PASF has changed over the years and how you can take advantage of everything it has to offer ‚Äî even the odd things. A brief history and the many faces of "People also search for" We first saw the words ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù in 2012 with the introduction of knowledge graphs. Bringing up the rear of this right-side SERP feature, the PASF portion (which is still with us today) contains a handful of image thumbnails atop topically-related terms. As part of the introduction, Google‚Äôs Amit Singhal had this to say about the PASF: ‚ÄúWe can now sometimes help answer your next question before you‚Äôve asked it because the facts we show are informed by what other people have searched for. For example, the information we show for Tom Cruise answers 37 percent of next queries that people ask about him.‚Äù After that, we saw the ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù act as an independent agent for a brief time, particularly for music-related queries. Divorced from the knowledge graph, the related topics (and images) were contained in their own box and placed at the bottom of the SERP. When right above the list of ‚ÄúSearches related to,‚Äù it‚Äôs easier for us to see the kind of distinction Google is trying to make between these similar SERP features. One can take you down several topically-connected rabbit holes (the PASF); the other can help you refine or expand on your current query (the ‚ÄúSearches related to‚Äù). In the example above for the query [can‚Äôt hold us], the PASF box thinks that given our taste in music, we may be interested in songs by the same artist or others that sound similar. The ‚ÄúSearches related to‚Äù section, on the other hand, is showing us different iterations of our same query. But that was back in early 2016. On the current [can‚Äôt hold us] SERP, that independent ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù box has popped back into the knowledge graph, leaving behind two boxes of related searches that both look and function the same but don‚Äôt bear the PASF name. This brings us to today and what you‚Äôre really here for ‚Äî in the middle of February, Google started returning desktop ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù results that look like this: Here, the thumbnail images have been abandoned, and the related topics now attach to an organic result. The topics also now seem to be a mix of the original PASF and ‚ÄúSearches related to.‚Äù In our example above for the query [munchkin cat], ‚Äúnapoleon cat,‚Äù ‚Äúskookum cat,‚Äù and ‚Äúdwarf calico cat,‚Äù are definitely more like the OG PASF suggestions, while the other three are similar to what you‚Äôd find at the bottom of the SERP. This is likely because the PASF box, stuck to an organic results, returns topics that relate to the URL and not the query. In order to surface this new version of the ‚ÄúPeople also search for,‚Äù you need to do a little pogo-sticking. The only way you‚Äôll see it materialize is by clicking the organic search result and then navigating back to the SERP. It seems to be saying, ‚ÄúDidn‚Äôt find what you‚Äôre looking for? Try these instead.‚Äù If it feels like you might be experiencing a touch of d√©j√† vu, it‚Äôs because you are. We‚Äôve seen this kind of PASF treatment on mobile devices since at least 2015. Now, onto the research! There are a lot of PASFs appearing on a lot of SERPs Digging into the data to see just how widespread this desktop rollout was, we found that the new ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù result type appeared on 58.74 percent of the roughly 15,000 desktop SERPs we analyzed each day for a week. This high of an amount, together with their established history on mobile SERPs (which they appear on 87.05 percent of), makes us fairly confident they‚Äôre more than just an experiment ‚Äî they‚Äôre here to stay and likely going to increase in scope. When looking at the number of PASFs that appear for a single keyword, we saw an average of 8.77 boxes per SERP, but SERPs with 10 PASFs occurred most frequently. We also found that the vast, vast majority of organic results with a PASF rank in positions 1‚Äì10. Parsing the 100-result SERP means that it‚Äôs not always easy for us to know where one page ends and another begins, but because of the rank clustering we see, we‚Äôre fairly positive the ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù box is in an exclusive relationship with the first page. Also, since this result is currently married to organic results, our SERPs without a few PASFs are more likely due to the presence of SERP features than organic results that simply don‚Äôt produce them ‚Äî though we have seen of few instances of that. You get six related topics per "people also search for" For reasons that remain somewhat unclear but we‚Äôll take a stab at anyway, desktop ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù boxes contain two fewer related topics than PASFs chillin‚Äô on mobile SERPs. 95.47 percent of our mobile PASFs had eight, while 96.81 percent of desktop PASFs had six. And the rest of the desktop boxes were equally likely to contain anywhere from 2‚Äì5 topics (Google seems to understand that one is the loneliest number and has refrained from leaving a single topic all on its own). Perhaps Google wanted to avoid creating a lengthy desktop SERP? Mobile PASFs employ carousel-like behavior, which means they can fit eight terms without creating an impossibly long SERP. We could also chalk the difference up to these being relatively early days of a rollout, so we‚Äôll definitely be keeping an eye on whether this changes, and we‚Äôre gladly taking alternate explanations in the meantime. Duplicate PASF topics make research doable Much like the ‚Äúalso asked‚Äù questions in a PAA, there is a lot of duplication in the topics that live in a PASF. Depending on your strategy, you can slice related topics by URL or query to help focus your research and keep it from scaling out of control. Taking the URL approach helps you see how many topics (and what kind) relate to those specific pages. For example, URLs that appeared more than once in our data set saw an average of 3.02 distinct topics per SERP. From a query perspective, we found that with an average of 54.46 related topics per SERP, 31.58 percent appeared more than once. If we‚Äôre rounding to the nearest whole topic, this means that one query can give us 37 unique related topics to explore. At first blush, this would create an impossibly large number of new topics to tackle the more keywords you track. But worry not! When we take our entire query space into consideration, our data set returned only 47 unique topics over the course of seven days ‚Äî a much more manageable number. After looking at the mobile side of things, it seems Google is intentionally keeping the scope of related topics narrow. Nearly half ‚Äî 46.35 percent ‚Äî of all terms in mobile ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù boxes are duplicates, which is even more duplication than our desktop PASFs. With up to 20 extra spots available per SERP, it‚Äôs unlikely that Google simply couldn‚Äôt think up new topics to slot in. Instead, it appears they‚Äôve determined that the best, most relevant topics are already in play. To sum this up: the duplication is weird but good. It means that you don‚Äôt need a lot of SERPs to get a fairly complete picture of topics associated with you, your competitors, or your queries. Sidestep tricky competitors by targeting the SERPs of PASF topics When clicked, topics in the ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù box becomes the search queries of whole new SERPs. Naturally, we wanted to see what stories those SERPs could tell. To do this, we gathered a day‚Äôs worth of PASF topics, stuffed them into STAT to track, and then did some comparing. And what we found was a somewhat puzzling relationship between domains on the subsequent SERP and those on the original. For starters, when you click a PASF topic that appears under a domain, 78.87 percent of the time that domain doesn‚Äôt rank anywhere in the top 20 of the new SERP. We take this to mean that either: Google knows better than to show you the same site you just left; or even though the site is topically-related, it‚Äôs not relevant enough for the new SERP. In the 21.13 percent of the time that the domain does appear in the top 20 of the subsequent SERP, the lower it ranked on the initial SERP, the higher it‚Äôs likely to be ranked on the new one. Huh. And, of those domains that did appear on the subsequent SERP and ranked in first place, 49.54 percent did so as a featured snippet (though we feel compelled to let you know that our sample size had been whittled down by quite a bit at this point). So, how‚Äôs an SEO to take advantage of all this oddity? Well, if you‚Äôre struggling to rank higher, or rank at all, against your current query‚Äôs competitors, it may be worth investigating the SERPs of PASF topics as alternate avenues. Combine PASF with PAA and start to conquer the SERP Once you‚Äôve got your paws on all the ‚ÄúPeople also search for‚Äù topics, collect everything in the ‚ÄúPeople also ask‚Äù boxes and then round up each of the ‚ÄúSearches related to.‚Äù Use these gifts from Google to map your query space, grow your keyword lists, and build out content that can hit multiple topics. Want to see how you can do this all in STAT? Book your personalized walkthrough, below! Book a demo! Copied! Back to Top
